U.S. Makes Shortlist for Saudi Nuclear-Plant Deal Saudi Arabia has put the U.S. on its shortlist of potential partners competing to build nuclear- power plants in the kingdom, while the two countries negotiate how to do a deal without spreading nuclear weapons, Energy Secretary Rick Perry said. IMF Expands Aid Package for Argentina The International Monetary Fund agreed to expand its $50 billion bailout package signed with Argentina in June, providing more money and accelerating the disbursement of funds. Argentina's Economy Contracted Amid Crisis Argentina's economy shrank in July from a year earlier as the country's financial crisis hit consumer demand and the lingering impact of a drought hurt agricultural activity. New Zealand Central Bank Keeps Rates On Ice New Zealand's central bank left its benchmark interest rate unchanged while continuing to leave its options open for the future, saying the next move could be up or down. (END) Dow Jones Newswires September 26, 2018 23:00 ET (03:00 GMT)

Title: UPDATE 2-Traders keep bets on U.S. Fed's 2019  interest rate  rises
Article: (Updates market action, adds quote) By Ann Saphir and Richard Leong Sept 26 (Reuters) - Interest rates futures traders on Wednesday stuck with bets the Federal Reserve will raise rates once more this year and two times next year even after the central bank released forecasts flagging a slightly steeper rate rise path. Contracts tied to the Fed's policy rate that are traded at CME Group's Chicago Board of Trade rose in the wake of the Fed's expected third rate increase in 2018 on Wednesday and after Fed Chairman Jerome Powell's upbeat comments on the economy after the Fed's two-day meeting. The higher pricing in the contracts was not large enough to alter traders' expectations for a Fed rate hike in December, which would bring it to a target range of 2.25 percent to 2.50 percent. It implied traders expect two more rate increases in 2019. Fed forecasts released on Wednesday showed Fed policymakers themselves view three rate hikes as likely needed next year. "The projected path on interest rates is the same," said Larry Milstein, head of government and agency trading at R.W. Pressprich & Co. in New York. "I think a December hike is pretty well baked in." Meanwhile, policy-makers ended their long-running characterization of their policy stance as "accommodative." The Fed "is probably close to being done raising rates even though they flagged a few more hikes," said Mark McCormick, head of TD Securities' North American FX strategy. With unemployment at 3.9 percent, well below what most Fed officials view as sustainable in the long run, inflation was still expected to creep only slightly above the central bank's 2.0 percent target, Fed forecasts released Wednesday show. Fed policymakers did not jack up their expectations for rate hikes in coming years, as some analysts had thought, instead sticking closely to rate hike path forecasts outlined in June that envision short-term rates, now at 2.0 percent to 2.25 percent, to be at 3.1 percent by the end of next year. Their latest rate projections, together with Powell's comment that the Fed does not expect upside surprise on inflation, spurred a wave of buying in longer-dated Treasuries. This trade flattened the yield curve, narrowing the spread between two-year and 10-year Treasury yields to just a tad less than 23 basis points, which was the tightest level in more than a week. (Additional reporting by Gertrude Chavez-Dreyfuss Editing by Chizu Nomiyama)

Title: Wall Street rally disintegrates shortly before the close
Article: (Reuters) - A Wall Street rally collapsed and stocks turned negative shortly before the market close on Wednesday after investors reassessed the Federal Reserve's policy statement and reduced their risk as they weighed how long the U.S. central bank would continue to raise interest rates. U.S. stocks initially extended gains after the Fed, as expected, raised interest rates and left its monetary policy outlook for the coming years largely unchanged amid steady economic growth and a strong job market. But the market reversed course as investors weighed to what degree the elimination of the word "accommodative" from the Fed's policy statement suggested that the end of a cycle of interest-rate hikes might be in sight. The Fed lifted its benchmark overnight lending rate by a quarter of a percentage point to a range of 2.00 percent to 2.25 percent. "People misinterpreted the removal of 'accommodative' in the statement," said Mike O'Rourke, chief market strategist at JonesTrading. "People realized that monetary policy remains on course and there are expectations of another rate hike this year, and they unwound purchases they made on the release of the statement, and also additional de-risking going into the close." The S&P 500 financial index <.SPSY> fell 1.27 percent, leading declines. The S&P 500 utilities index <.SPLRCU> and real estate index <.SPLRCR>, which are sensitive to interest rates because their components are often favored for their dividend yields, each fell over 1 percent. The Fed still foresees another rate hike in December, three more next year, and one increase in 2020. Fed Chairman Jerome Powell said after the policy meeting that the U.S. central bank is closely monitoring inflation, underscoring concerns the U.S. economy's rapid growth could lead to overheating and force the Fed to raise rates further. Referring to the removal of the word "accommodative," Powell said, "This change does not signal any change in the likely path of policy. Instead, it is a sign that policy is proceeding in line with our expectations.” The stock market has enjoyed a boom period and is at record levels. But as rates rise, equities face rising competition for investors' funds not only from bonds, but also from cash, which is now the most attractive it has been in about a decade. The Dow Jones Industrial Average <.DJI> ended down 0.4 percent at 26,385.28 points, while the S&P 500 <.SPX> lost 0.33 percent to 2,905.97. During the session, the S&P 500 traded up as much as 0.53 percent. The Nasdaq Composite <.IXIC> dropped 0.21 percent to 7,990.37. The S&P 500 health index <.SPXHC> rose 0.20 percent, led by biotechs, while the newly formed communication services index <.SPLRCL> rose 0.35 percent, boosted by Facebook <FB.O>, which gained 1.24 percent. Twenty-First Century Fox <FOXA.O> rose 1.02 percent after agreeing to sell its stake in Sky <SKYB.L> to Comcast <CMCSA.O>, which dipped 0.08 percent. Walt Disney Co <DIS.N>, which is buying Fox, jumped 1.39 percent. Nike <NKE.N> fell 1.3 percent as the sportswear maker stuck to its full-year forecast even after sales got a boost from a controversial ad campaign featuring former NFL player Colin Kaepernick. Declining issues outnumbered advancing ones on the NYSE by a 1.60-to-1 ratio; on Nasdaq, a 1.70-to-1 ratio favored decliners. The S&P 500 posted 31 new 52-week highs and 12 new lows; the Nasdaq Composite recorded 66 new highs and 73 new lows. Volume on U.S. exchanges was 7.0 billion shares, compared to a 6.7 billion average over the last 20 trading days. (Reporting by Noel Randewitch; Additional reporting by Amy Caren Daniel in Bengaluru and Caroline Valetkevitch in New York; Editing by Leslie Adler)

Title: Update: Dow's Post-Fed Gains Capped By Weakness In Goldman, JPMorgan And AmEx Stocks -- MarketWatch
Article: The Dow Jones Industrial Average Wednesday afternoon was holding on to tenuous gains after the Federal Reserve raised interest rates, as expected, with benchmark U.S. government bond rates failing to push significantly higher thereafter. The Dow was up about 0.1% at 26,571, with shares of components Goldman Sachs Group Inc. (GS), American Express Co. (AXP) and JPMorgan Chase & Co. (JPM) all trading lower following the Fed's decision to lift rates to a range of 2% to 2.25%, marking its third rate increase of 2018, with the central bank setting the stage for a fourth in December. The Federal Open Market Committee also removed the term "accommodative," in characterizing its monetary policy, and Fed Chairman Jerome Powell emphasized during a 2:30 p.m. Eastern news conference following the release of the Fed's updated policy package, that policy, in fact, remains accommodative, but wanted to signal that the domestic economy is getting stronger. Still, financials sank as the 10-year Treasury yield fell to around 3.06%, compared with 3.08% prior to the Fed decision at 2 p.m. A popular gauge of the financial sector, Financial Select Sector SPDR ETF (XLF), was down 0.8%, representing the worst performing sector in the S&P 500 index . Ordinarily, banks' business models benefit from a rising interest-rate environment. -Mark DeCambre For more from MarketWatch: http://www.marketwatch.com/newsviewer (END) Dow Jones Newswires September 26, 2018 16:31 ET (20:31 GMT)

Title: What a Fed rate hike means for you, at any age
Article: No matter your age, what the Federal Reserve does to interest rates will most likely affect you. The central bank raised what's called the federal funds rate by a quarter of a percentage point to a range of 2 percent to 2.25 percent Wednesday, the third such increase this year. An increase creates a ripple effect for rates on a variety of loans and investments. "Interest rates are going up across a broad range of consumer borrowing," said Fed Chairman Jerome Powell at a press conference following the rate increase. But Powell pointed out that rates are "still quite low by historical levels." Higher rates can mean different things to people, depending on where they are in life. In general, for people borrowing money, it means life is getting more expensive. For savers, it means slightly bigger rewards. Here's a look at some of the effects: FOR 20-SOMETHINGS What's rising even faster than college tuitions? The financing costs to pay for them. Student-loan rates have been climbing along with the yield on the 10-year Treasury note, which has risen above 3 percent. Undergraduate students taking out federal direct loans this school year will pay a fixed 5.05 percent interest rate. That's a significant jump from the 4.45 percent rate of the prior school year, and it's the highest since 2009-10, when it was 5.6 percent. The rate is fixed, so direct federal loans taken out for the 2018-19 academic year will keep the 5.05 percent rate. The Fed reiterated Wednesday that it expects to raise rates one more time this year and another three times in 2019. Unless that changes, long-term rates would also rise, so student loans taken out next year will likely have a higher rate. Interest rates for private loans are already traditionally higher and will likely rise as well. Additionally, it's easy in your 20s to start to slide down the slippery slope of credit card debt. Try to resist because carrying a balance is only going to get more expensive ahead. Credit card rates are most sensitive to changes in the federal funds rate, almost directly matching the rate change with a 1.92-point increase since late 2015 when the Fed began to hike rates, said Nick Clements, co-founder of MagnifyMoney.com, a financial information website. Clements estimates that with this latest hike, the average household that carries credit card debt month to month will pay over $150 in extra interest per year compared with before the rate hikes began. MagnifyMoney estimates 122 million Americans carry credit card debt month to month. FOR YOUNG(ISH) WORKERS - 30s and 40s It's a busy time financially — people in this age group may be focused on paying down debts such as auto loans, mortgages and student loans while also trying to stoke their savings. Pay off any variable-rate debts ASAP. That means paying down credit cards, home equity lines of credit and student loans from private lenders as quickly as possible before these borrowing costs rise. To put this in perspective, since the Fed began raising rates, the average credit card rate has jumped from 15.78 percent to 17.32 percent; the average home equity line of credit has climbed from 4.75 percent to 6.08 percent, according to Bankrate.com. And those with adjustable rate mortgages expecting a rate reset this year will see the rate jump to 5.25 percent or more. Speaking of mortgages, because interest rates are on an upward trajectory, new mortgage debt will also most likely be getting more expensive. The fed funds rate and mortgages don't always move in lockstep for a number of reasons. But since late 2015, the average 30-year fixed mortgage rate has increased from approximately 3.9 percent to 4.6 percent, as of Sept. 13. If you are looking for a mortgage, shop around for the best rate. If you have an adjustable rate mortgage that is expected to reset higher soon, consider refinancing to a lower fixed-rate now. Meanwhile, members of this group should also save for retirement and build up their emergency savings. For the latter, consider banking online, where you can find numerous savings accounts with rates around 2 percent. FOR NEAR-RETIREMENT OR RETIRED — 50, 60, 70 AND BEYOND Huzzah. Savers are finally earning more on their cash — if only just a bit. The national rate for a 12-month CD is 0.45 percent, according to the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. That sounds like a pittance of interest, but it's double the rate from a couple years ago. Rates for longer-term CDs are also rising, and the national rate for a five-year CD is up to 1.11 percent from 0.87 percent a year ago. Such low figures mean many savers still aren't keeping up with inflation, but analysts expect rates to continue trending higher. Savers can also typically find better rates at online banks than at traditional ones — they sometimes even match the rate of inflation, which was 2.7 percent last month. For a three-year CD, several online banks offer rates at that level or slightly higher. Now on to those investments you worked so hard on. Higher interest rates hurt investors with bond funds in their 401(k) accounts, at least in the short term. A rise in rates makes the bonds sitting in a bond fund's portfolio suddenly less attractive, when compared against newly issued bonds that are paying more in interest. That causes those bonds' prices to drop, and the dynamic has caused many of the most popular bond funds to lose money this year. The largest bond fund by assets is down 2.1 percent through Monday, for example. But those funds will also be earning more in interest thanks to the higher rates and should be able to offset those losses in the long run, as long as rates rise gradually. Stock funds should also feel an effect, and emerging-market funds have been among the biggest losers recently. But as long as the rise in rates is due to a strengthening economy, rather than fears about a surge in inflation, analysts say stock funds should be able to hold steady. That's because a better economy usually spells higher corporate profits. ART FILE- In this Sept. 19, 2014, file photo, morning commuters ride a water taxi up the Chicago River to Michigan Avenue in Chicago. No matter your age, what the Federal Reserve does to interest rates will most likely affect you. Economists say the central bank is nearly certain to raise what’s called the federal funds rate by a quarter of a percentage point on Wednesday, Sept. 26, 2018, the third such increase this year. (AP Photo/M. Spencer Green, File) | FILE- In this March 21, 2018, file photo Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell looks to his notes as he speaks during a news conference following the Federal Open Market Committee meeting in Washington. No matter your age, what the Federal Reserve does to interest rates will most likely affect you. Economists say the central bank is nearly certain to raise what’s called the federal funds rate by a quarter of a percentage point on Wednesday, Sept. 26, 2018, the third such increase this year. (AP Photo/Carolyn Kaster, File)

Title: Dow's Post-Fed Gains Capped By Weakness In Goldman, JPMorgan And AmEx Stocks -- MarketWatch
Article: The Dow Jones Industrial Average Wednesday afternoon was holding on to tenuous gains after the Federal Reserve raised interest rates, as expected, with benchmark U.S. government bond rates failing to push significantly higher thereafter. The Dow was up about 0.1% at 26,571, with shares of components Goldman Sachs Group Inc. (GS), American Express Co. (AXP) and JPMorgan Chase & Co. (JPM) all trading lower following the Fed's decision to lift rates to a range of 2% to 2.25%, marking its third rate increase of 2018, with the central bank setting the stage for a fourth in December. The Federal Open Market Committee also removed the term "accommodative," in characterizing its monetary policy, and Fed Chairman Jerome Powell emphasized during a 2:30 p.m. Eastern news conference following the release of the Fed's updated policy package, that policy, in fact, remains accommodative, but wanted to signal that the domestic economy is getting stronger. Still, financials sank as the 10-year Treasury yield fell to around 3.06%, compared with 3.08% prior to the Fed decision at 2 p.m. A popular gauge of the financial sector, Financial Select Sector SPDR ETF (XLF), was down 0.8%, representing the worst performing sector in the S&P 500 index . Ordinarily, banks' business models benefit from a rising interest-rate environment. -Mark DeCambre For more from MarketWatch: http://www.marketwatch.com/newsviewer (END) Dow Jones Newswires September 26, 2018 15:13 ET (19:13 GMT)

Title: Powell Not Worried By Trump's Monetary Policy Pot Shots -- Market Talk
Article: 1445 ET - In his press conference after the FOMC meeting, Fed Chairman Jerome Powell was asked about whether President Donald Trump's criticism of rate rises are a problem. Powell doesn't say the president's name and falls back on central bank boilerplate, noting "we don't consider political factors or things like that" when making policy. Instead, he says the Fed focuses on its mission. (michael.derby@wsj.com) 1415 ET - US government bond yields tick lower, then pare their declines, after the Federal Reserve raises short-term interest rates and removes the word "accommodative" from its policy statement. Investors had been widely expecting the central bank to raise rates in September, but had been less sure of whether the Fed would signal a more aggressive approach to future rate increases. That had driven yields higher heading into Wednesday's meeting, although traders said on first glance, the Fed's latest policy statement didn't strike them as being hawkish. The yield on the benchmark 10-year US Treasury note fell to around 3.065% before recently trading at 3.078%, compared with 3.102% Tuesday. (akane.otani@wsj.com; @akaneotani) 1411 ET - The Fed's interest rate forecasts may not hold any great surprises relative to what was seen in June, but it's notable that central bankers see an extended period of time of running monetary policy above its long run level. The Fed may be dispensing with descriptions of policy as "accommodative" and Fed Chairman Jerome Powell may be pushed the concept of neutral rates off to the margin. Still, against the Fed's estimate of a long-term fed funds target rate of 3%, they see monetary policy delivering rates above that in 2019, 2020 and 2021. Given the duration of the business cycle, trade war rumblings and the worries about the yield curve, it will be very interesting to see if the Fed can deliver on such a hawkish policy outlook. (michael.derby@wsj.com) 1410 ET - The September Federal Reserve policy statement showed no change in officials' characterization of the economy and its strength compared with the previous policy statement. Officials said the labor market has continued to strengthen, while the economy has been rising at a strong pace. Meanwhile, inflation remains near the central bank's 2% target. The main change in September's statement, other than the rate increase decision, was the drop of "accommodative" in the description of interest rates. (sarah.chaney@wsj.com) 1407 ET - Twelve of 16 Fed officials now expect four interest rate increases this year, more than in previous months, according to new economic projections. In June, eight Fed officials expected at least four rate rises in 2018. The higher number of officials projecting four rate bumps signals a stronger belief among officials that the economy is running strong, necessitating gradual rate increases to keep it from overheating. (sarah.chaney@wsj.com) 1404 ET - Federal Reserve officials removed language in their policy statement that had described short-term interest rates as "accommodative," meaning they are still low enough to stimulate economic growth. Most officials think rates are still accommodative but are becoming less so with each rate increase, and are on track to reach a neutral level that neither spurs nor slows growth in coming months. The problem is officials' aren't sure where neutral lies or when they'll get there. Waiting until later this year or next year to drop the phrase would have risked sending an unintended message then that they agreed they were at neutral, which they are unlikely to do, given the uncertainties involved. (sarah.chaney@wsj.com) 1402 ET - Central bank officials voted to raise their benchmark federal-funds rate by a quarter-percentage point to a range between 2% and 2.25%, according to Wednesday's policy statement. The decision to raise interest rates for the third time this year is in line with expectations for the Fed to gradually raise rates as the economy remains on a path of strength. The bigger question is how Fed Chairman Jerome Powell might characterize the balance of risks at the press conference. (sarah.chaney@wsj.com) 1341 ET - One key thing to watch after the Fed meeting, assuming a rate rise happens, is what happens with the yield curve. The difference between two and 10-year Treasury securities continues to stand within spitting distance of going negative, with the spread currently right around 25 basis points. It's possible a rate rise or two more, which the Fed could easily deliver this year, could kick that spread into negative territory, with ominous portents for the economic outlook. Some key Fed officials like New York Fed leader John Williams have downplayed this relationship, but others, like St Louis' James Bullard, have cautioned against doing the "this time it's different" argument. (michael.derby@wsj.com) 1325 ET - This year's rate tightening campaign has been met with not a single dissenting vote. That's unlikely to change today, as all of the voting members have indicated they're on board with further action. Personal shifts, most notably John Williams moving from the San Francisco Fed to New York, haven't altered the balance. There will be one new voting member with the entrance of Richard Clarida as vice-chair, but nobody expects him to dissent. Perhaps the one curiosity in FOMC voting patterns this year has been Raphael Bostic in Atlanta, the first African-American regional bank head in the Fed's history. Left leaning activists wanted a minority, believing such a person would be more sensitive to how marginalized groups experience monetary policy. But by and large, Bostic has been on board with rate rises, even when the activists opposed them. FOMC voting patterns may become more interesting with the final two meetings, when Mary Daly takes over in San Francisco. (michael.derby@wsj.com) 1255 ET - Capital Economics notes today that over the last year, the Fed really hasn't run down its balance sheet all that much. So far, its only shed about $250B off what was $4.5 trillion in holdings. They also note that at the current pace it won't be until 2021 that the balance sheet goes under the $3 trillion mark. Capital Economics observes in its note that credit activity has been wholly unaffected by balance sheet shrinkage. On the upside for the Fed, the drawdown continues to be a complete nonevent for financial markets. About the only time the balance sheet has bubbled up as an issue is when some speculated tweaks to the Fed's drawdown strategy could help ward off an inversion of the yield curve. (michael.derby@wsj.com) Corrections & Amplifications This item was corrected at 1:12 p.m. ET because it misspelled Capital Economics in the headline. It should read, Capital Economics. 1154 ET - Fitch Ratings has upgraded Bank of Cyprus to BB+ from BB, one step before investment grade. The update follows the announcement that the bank agreed to sold a portfolio of EUR2.8 billion of gross loans, including EUR2.7 billion of non-performing loans, equivalent to about a third of the bank's total NPLs. According to Fitch Ratings, the transaction "will be positive for the BoC's credit risk profile and will reduce capital encumbrance by unreserved problem assets." It is expected to be finalised by end-2018 or first quarter of next year. It expresses the view that "the execution risk on the transaction is small given the strong incentives for all involved parties to complete the deal." (nektaria.stamouli@wsj.com) 1117 ET - Emerging markets are likely to experience further weakness, says Rabobank. The economic slowdown in China "will not only be a drag on the value of the remnibi versus the dollar in the months ahead" but it will dampen investors' risk appetite "for some time." Ebbing risk appetite is "detrimental" to emerging market assets. "In contrast, strong growth and higher yields in the U.S. are likely to continue supporting broad-based dollar," which has been behind most of the fall in emerging market assets. (olga.cotaga@wsj.com) (END) Dow Jones Newswires September 26, 2018 14:45 ET (18:45 GMT)

Title: Update: Fed Lifts Interest Rates, No Longer Says Policy Is 'accommodative' -- MarketWatch
Article: The Federal Reserve voted unanimously to lift a key U.S. interest rate by a quarter point, but the central bank is sticking to its gradualist strategy of raising the cost of borrowing. The Fed predicts one more rate hike by December and three more in 2019, unchanged from its prior forecast. After a two-day meeting, the Fed on Wednesday raised its short-term fed funds rate to a range of 2% to 2.25%, marking the highest level in a decade. In a surprising twist, though, the Fed dropped longstanding language from its policy statement saying its monetary policy "remains accommodative." The removal of that phrase suggests the Fed could even pause at some point to assess the effect of its actions on the economy. The FOMC boosted its forecast for U.S. growth in 2018 to 3.1% from 2.8%, but it expects GDP to eventually slow to as low as 1.8% by 2021. -Jeffry Bartash For more from MarketWatch: http://www.marketwatch.com/newsviewer (END) Dow Jones Newswires September 26, 2018 14:09 ET (18:09 GMT)

Title: * Federal Reserve  Changes Fed Funds Range to 2.00% to 2.25%
Article: 26 Sep 2018 14:00 ET *Fed Raises Interest Rates, Signals One More Increase This Year 26 Sep 2018 14:00 ET *Fed Removes 'Accommodative' Wording From Statement 26 Sep 2018 14:00 ET *Fed Leaves Unchanged Wording on Economy, Labor Market, Inflation 26 Sep 2018 14:00 ET *Fed: Labor Market Has Continued to Strengthen 26 Sep 2018 14:00 ET *Fed: Economic Activity Has Been Rising At A Strong Rate 26 Sep 2018 14:00 ET *Fed: Household Spending, Business Investment Have Grown Strongly 26 Sep 2018 14:00 ET *Fed: Job Gains Have Been Strong, On Average 26 Sep 2018 14:00 ET *Fed: Jobless Rate Has Stayed Low 26 Sep 2018 14:00 ET *Fed: Risks To Economic Outlook Appear Roughly Balanced 26 Sep 2018 14:00 ET *Fed: Indicators Of Longer-Term Inflation Expectations 'Little Changed' 26 Sep 2018 14:00 ET *Fed Expects Further Gradual Rate Increases Consistent With Sustained Expansion 26 Sep 2018 14:00 ET *Fed Raises Discount Rate 0.25-Pt to 2.75% 26 Sep 2018 14:00 ET *FOMC: Voted 9-0 For Fed Funds Rate Action 26 Sep 2018 14:00 ET  Fed Raises Interest Rates, Signals One More Increase This Year By Nick Timiraos WASHINGTON-The Federal Reserve said it will raise short-term interest rates by another quarter-percentage point, and officials signaled they want to continue lifting them through the next year to keep a strong economy on an even keel. Officials voted unanimously Wednesday on the increase, which will bring the benchmark federal-funds rate to a range between 2% and 2.25%. Most officials expect to raise rates one more time this year, according to new projections released after the meeting. The increase is the third this year and the eighth since the Fed began to lift rates in late 2015 after keeping them pinned near zero after the 2008 financial crisis. Wednesday's decision marks the first time that the Fed has raised rates above 2% since a series of rate cuts that followed the government's intervention in March 2008 to prevent the liquidation of Bear Stearns Cos. It also is the first time in a decade rates will rise above inflation, measured by the Fed's preferred gauge, excluding volatile energy and food categories. So-called core prices rose 2% in July. The Fed over the past year has returned interest rates to a more normal setting while also gradually reducing its $4.2 trillion portfolio of bonds and other assets. The big question now is how much further officials think they need to go to raise rates to keep the economy from overheating. The Fed targets a 2% inflation rate, which it sees as a sign of healthy demand. It wants to avoid economic growth that becomes unsustainable, leading to a boom and then bust. Altogether, these moves should ripple through the economy by steadily raising borrowing costs for businesses and consumers. Rising mortgage rates, for example, appear to have slowed home sales this year. Higher borrowing costs steal pricing power from sellers who have benefited from rising prices in recent years. Fed officials removed a phrase from their post-meeting statement that for years has described their rate stance as "accommodative," meaning they are pressing on the gas pedal to help stimulate growth. Dropping the language now doesn't necessarily signal that officials believe rates are no longer low enough to stimulate growth. Instead, the change reflects how officials, including Fed Chairman Jerome Powell, want to move away from providing overly precise estimates of where such a neutral setting stands given the inherent uncertainty in such measures. The Fed made no other changes to its statement, which it has now purged of nearly all references to the future stance of monetary policy. Removing such forward guidance reflects how the central bank is moving into a new phase of policy setting that could be more uncertain. Twelve of 16 officials now expect the Fed will raise rates a total of four times this year, up from eight of 15 officials in June and just four of 16 last December. Most officials expect the Fed would need to raise rates at least three more times next year and once more in 2020. Most officials see the Fed refraining from additional rate increases after that, leaving rates in a range between 3.25% and 3.5% by the end of 2020 and through 2021. The new interest-rate guidance shows most Fed officials believe they will need to raise short-term rates slightly beyond the level they expect is likely to prevail when supply and demand are perfectly balanced. Two thirds of officials expect that longer-run rate sits around 2.75% or 3%. Fed officials have upgraded their economic outlook over the past year, first because of a synchronized upturn in global growth beginning last summer, and later after Congress approved stimulus in the form of tax cuts and increased federal spending. Officials made few changes to their economic projections in September. The median projection now sees gross domestic product rising 3.1% this year, up from 2.8% in June and 2.7% in March. Officials continued to estimate the economy's long run growth rate sits at 1.8% and that growth will return to that level by 2021. Officials nudged up their unemployment forecast. They expect the jobless rate will end the year at 3.7%, versus a projection of 3.6% in June. That is still below all officials' estimates of the level of unemployment they expect to prevail over the long run. Estimates of this so-called natural rate of unemployment range from 4% to 4.6%. Their inflation projections were virtually unchanged. All officials see inflation holding between 2% and 2.3% over the coming years after several years in which the Fed struggled to reach the target. Just how much more the Fed continues to raise rates will depend largely on whether inflation behaves as they expect it to. One camp of officials says so long as unemployment keeps falling farther below the level that they project is consistent with stable prices, the Fed will need to raise rates to prevent the economy from overheating. This is an uncontroversial strategy because it is what the central bank always does at this point in an expansion. Another camp argues for a relatively radical departure from this norm. These officials say if inflation doesn't appear to be accelerating beyond 2%, the Fed could stop raising rates after reaching a "neutral" setting designed to neither spur nor slow growth. Mr. Powell hasn't revealed his preference, but in an August speech he sounded sympathetic to treating the traditional models more skeptically than some of his colleagues or staff. Given the strength of the U.S. economy, turbulence abroad represents perhaps the biggest risk to the Fed's plans. In 2015 and 2016, officials held back planned rate increases due to upheaval in global markets, mostly emanating from China. The Fed could be forced to reconsider its plans if something similar occurs, for example, if a stronger dollar triggers upheaval in emerging markets, which in turns spills into China amid rising trade tensions with the U.S. (END) Dow Jones Newswires September 26, 2018 14:00 ET (18:00 GMT)

Title: CANADA FX DEBT-C$ treads water ahead of expected U.S. Fed rate hike
Article: * Canadian dollar at 1.2955 to greenback, or 77.19 US cents * Price of U.S. oil falls 0.6 percent * Canadian bond prices trade mixed across the yield curve TORONTO, Sept 26 (Reuters) - The Canadian dollar was little changed against its U.S. counterpart on Wednesday, trading in a narrow range as oil prices fell and the U.S. dollar climbed ahead of an expected interest rate hike by the U.S. Federal Reserve. At 8:59 a.m. (1259 GMT), the Canadian dollar          was nearly unchanged at 1.2955 to the greenback, or 77.19 U.S. cents. The currency, which last Thursday touched its strongest level in more than three months at 1.2885, traded in a narrow range of 1.2945 to 1.2966. The U.S. dollar        rose against a basket of major currencies before a widely anticipated Fed rate hike priced in by investors still on edge about a trade row between the United States and China. Canada has its own trade dispute with the United States and is in slow-moving talks to renew the North American Free Trade Agreement (NAFTA). The country is not making concessions needed to reach a deal with the United States for a trilateral NAFTA pact and is running out of time before Washington proceeds with a Mexico-only agreement, a top U.S. official said on Tuesday. As the month-end deadline for the trade talks nears, Canadian executives who hedge foreign exchange risk have been changing their strategies so their companies can profit from any possible swings in the Canadian dollar. The price of oil, one of Canada's major exports, eased but was still heading for a fifth consecutive quarter of gains, driven by an impending drop in Iranian exports in the last three months of the year when global demand heats up. U.S. crude        prices were down 0.6 percent at $71.84 a barrel. Canadian government bond prices were mixed across the yield curve, with the 10-year             rising 1 Canadian cent to yield 2.459 percent. On Tuesday, the 10-year yield touched its highest intraday in more than four months at 2.472 percent. Bank of Canada Governor Stephen Poloz is due to speak on Thursday, while Canadian gross domestic product data for July is due on Friday. (Reporting by Fergal Smith; Editing by Jeffrey Benkoe)

Title: Real Time Economics: How Much Higher Will the Fed Lift Rates? | U.S. Ready to Boot Canada from Nafta | Consumer Confidence Hits 18-Year High
Article: This is the web version of the WSJ's newsletter on the economy. You can sign up for daily delivery here. Good morning. Today we look at the Federal Reserve's path for interest rates, the future of Nafta, and absolutely exuberant American consumers. HIGHER AND HIGHER The Federal Reserve is set to raise short-term interest rates Wednesday -- the eighth increase since late 2015 and third this year. It doesn't look like officials are ready to stop. At their June meeting, a narrow majority projected the Fed would raise rates a total of four times in 2018. That group is likely to grow this week. The bigger question: What happens next year? The WSJ's Nick Timiraos writes that there are two schools of thought. 1.) Conventional wisdom : Low and falling unemployment means the Fed will need to raise rates to slow the economy and prevent it from overheating. 2.) Radical departure : As long as inflation doesn't appear to be accelerating beyond 2%, the Fed could stop raising rates after reaching a "neutral" setting designed to neither spur nor slow growth. Extra: We'll also get revised projections on future rate moves (the dot plot) and the economy. Finally, Fed Chairman Jerome Powell steps up to the mic at 2:30 p.m. ET to hash it all out with reporters. Do you think the Fed needs to keep raising rates to cool off an overheating economy? Write to Jeffrey Sparshott at realtimeeconomics@wsj.com, tweet to @WSJecon and visit wsj.com/economy for the latest news. (Responses may be quoted in this newsletter.) WHAT TO WATCH TODAY U.S. new-home sales for August, out at 10 a.m. ET, are expected to edge up to an annual pace of 630,000 from 627,000. The Federal Reserve releases a policy statement and economic projections at 2 p.m., and Chairman Jerome Powell holds a press conference at 2:30 p.m. ET. President Trump spends another day at the United Nations. He's set to meet separately with the prime ministers of Israel, Japan and the United Kingdom. TOP STORIES KEEP ON LIFTING The Fed influences interest rates across the economy, but it doesn't dictate them. Average rates for credit cards, auto loans and home-equity lines of credit have all drifted higher as the Fed lifted its benchmark. The rate on a 30-year fixed-rate mortgage is now at the highest level since 2011, according to Freddie Mac. But the average rate on a 5-year new-car loan is still lower than in 2011, when the Fed's benchmark federal-funds rate was near zero, according to Bankrate.com. Ultimately, consumer borrowing costs are set in the markets based on a variety of factors, Paul Kiernan reports. ADIOS, CANADA The Trump administration's top trade negotiator threatened to move forward with a bilateral accord with Mexico amid a lack of progress with Canada on renegotiating the North American Free Trade Agreement. The Trump administration's threat raises uncertainties for business leaders and farmers: the treaty has allowed automobile makers and other industries to create supply chains that span the continent. A bilateral trade deal would disrupt those supply chains and raise the possibility of a eventual price increases, William Mauldin reports. There's an end-of-month deadline to reach a deal. I WON'T BACK DOWN President Trump criticized international organizations and alliances as unaccountable and defended his administration's hard-line trade policies at the United Nations General Assembly. "We will not allow our workers to be victimized, our companies to be cheated and our wealth to be plundered and transferred," he said. "America will never apologize for protecting our citizens." WINS AND LOSSES The conventional wisdom is that a trade war will hit U.S. partners harder than the U.S. But a paper by the European Central Bank estimates that a trade war with the rest of the world could knock about 2% off of U.S. economic growth, while China and other economies could gain. ECB economists modeled a scenario in which the U.S. raises tariffs on all of its imports by 10 percentage points, and its trading partners retaliate in kind. The higher tariffs would reduce household incomes and hurt business confidence, weighing on private consumption and investment, Tom Fairless writes. WHAT'S WRONG WITH BEING CONFIDENT? U.S. consumer confidence hit an 18-year high in September as robust job growth and a strong economic outlook bolstered Americans' expectations for the future. The latest reading suggests Americans aren't too worried about trade tensions. Instead, lofty sentiment bodes well for consumer spending and economic growth, Harriet Torry writes. Macroeconomic Advisers is tracking third-quarter gross domestic product at a 3.3% annual pace and the Atlanta Fed's GDPNow model is forecasting 4.4%. TWEET OF THE DAY I mean, imagine not being able to get along with Canada. -- Justin Wolfers (@JustinWolfers) September 25, 2018 WHAT ELSE WE'RE READING Men are doves and women are hawks. "[T]his column finds that for the same level of inflation, a higher share of women on the central bank board is associated with a higher interest rate. The findings suggest that women in central banks have a more hawkish attitude, and that heterogeneity of monetary policy committees can have an impact on monetary policy decisions," Donato Masciandaro, Paola Profeta and Davide Romelli write at the Center for Economic Policy Research. Women do better in science, tech, engineering and math when there are other women in their programs. "[W]e show that women entering cohorts with no female peers are 11.9pp less likely to graduate within 6 years than their male counterparts. A 1 [standard deviation] increase in the percentage of female students differentially increases the probability of on-time graduation for women by 4.6pp," Valerie Bostwick and Bruce Weinberg write in a National Bureau of Economic Research working paper. UP NEXT: THURSDAY The Bank of Japan's Haruhiko Kuroda speaks in Tokyo at 2:35 a.m. ET. Germany's consumer-price index is out at 8 a.m. ET. U.S. trade in goods for August is out at 8:30 a.m. ET. U.S. durable goods orders for August, out at 8:30 a.m. ET, are expected to climb 2.1% from the prior month. U.S. second-quarter gross domestic product, out at 8:30 a.m. ET, is expected to advance at 4.3% pace, a slight upward revision from the prior reading. U.S. jobless claims hit a fresh half-century low earlier this month. The latest numbers are out at 8:30 a.m. The European Central Bank's Mario Draghi speaks in Frankfurt at 9:30 a.m. ET. The Bank of England's Mark Carney chairs a panel in Frankfurt at 10 a.m. ET. U.S. pending-home sales for August are out at 10 a.m. ET. The Kansas City Fed's manufacturing survey for September is out at 11 a.m. ET. The Federal Reserve's Jerome Powell delivers brief remarks at an event in the Senate at 4:30 p.m. ET. The Bank of Canada's Stephen Poloz speaks in New Brunswick at 5:45 p.m. ET. (END) Dow Jones Newswires September 26, 2018 06:48 ET (10:48 GMT)

Title: Fed's Introduction of 2021 Rate Projections May Cap Short-Term Rates: ING -- Market Talk
Article: 1006 GMT - The Federal Reserve in its monetary policy announcement on Wednesday could introduce the 2021 dot in its "dot plot" interest-rate projections. If the median dot remains at 3.4%, that "would put an end-date on the hiking cycle," ING says. This would "cap short-term U.S. rates for now," as well as the dollar, according to ING. "The projections are typically extended by one year at September meetings and here the focus will be on where officials see policy heading in 2021." The Fed decision is at 1800 GMT. (olga.cotaga@wsj.com) 0955 GMT - Market participants are pricing in 50 basis points of interest rate increases by the Federal Reserve in 2019, and if the Fed says later on Wednesday that it no longer sees its policy as "accommodative", these expectations won't extend much further, says ING. "If the Fed were to no longer see U.S. monetary policy as being accommodative...one could infer that we are now in the latter stages of the tightening cycle - with policy approaching a neutral stance." Therefore, "policy moves may well be more data and market dependent - meaning limited need for investors to price in further Fed tightening." The Fed is expected to raise rates on Wednesday by 25 bps to 2.25%. (olga.cotaga@wsj.com) 0948 GMT - The Italian government is eventually likely to respect the fiscal rules because "they need financial markets on their side to raise funding for at least part of their plans," says Silvia Dall'Angelo, senior economist at Hermes Investment Management. The budget, to be presented on Thursday, might show a fiscal deficit of 1.6% to 2% of GDP for 2019, higher than last year's but roughly in line with this year's expected outcome, and is likely to be "reluctantly accepted by Brussels," she says. Ms. Dall'Angelo says gradualism will probably be the government's key word and the budget plan will probably include some watered-down versions of the promised policies. (emese.bartha@wsj.com' @EmeseBartha) 0945 GMT - Independent credit research firm CreditSights holds an "underperform" recommendation on Vodafone bonds, it says as the telecommuncations company comes to the market with a four-tranche multi-currency hybrid issuance. The recommendation reflects Vodafone's willingness to raise leverage to fill its infrastructure gap versus incumbents, while pressure in its core European markets, combined with spectrum auctions act as a headwind to near-term deleveraging, CreditSights says. That said, it expects Vodafone's hybrid deal to go well. The issuance comes more at fair value than necessarily cheap but technicals are supportive given scarcity and diversification benefits, CreditSights says. (emese.bartha@wsj.com; @EmeseBartha) 0943 GMT - A rate increase by the Czech central bank on Wednesday seems to be a "done deal," says Komercni's analyst Dalimil Vyskovsky, adding that the board is likely to point to a weaker currency as the main reason for the increase. The reaction of the EUR/CZK, currently trading flat at 25.5903, could be key, he says. If the Czech koruna weakens, then the market "might restart pricing more hikes going forward, though we still have some 80% of the November tightening priced in," he says. (emese.bartha@wsj.com; @EmeseBartha) 0912 GMT - The greenback moving little ahead of today's Fed pronouncement has meant little doing for currencies generally. But maybe the Singapore dollar will ease some afterward. UOB estimates the currency is 1.2% above the midpoint of its nominal effective exchange-rate band and predicts the local currency will trade 0.5-1.5% above it. Versus the US dollar, that implies a range of S$1.3623-1.3759 based on currency levels this morning. The greenback remains around S$1.3650. (gaurav.raghuvanshi@wsj.com) 0831 GMT - The central bank in the Czech Republic is expected to raise interest rates by 25 basis points to 1.50% when it announces a policy decision at 1100 GMT, but this is unlikely to move the Czech koruna. The decision is widely anticipated and already priced into the currency, as is a further rate rise to 1.75% by the end of this year, says UniCredit. "Barring any new signals coming from the CNB today, which we do not expect, EUR/CZK has likely built out a base at current levels," UniCredit says. EUR/CZK is last down 0.1% at 25.5833. "From current levels, we believe the risk is still to the upside for EUR/CZK." (olga.cotaga@wsj.com) 0815 GMT - Emerging market currencies "are not out of the woods" even though a Federal Reserveinterest rate increase later on Wednesday is widely expected, says UniCredit. The simultaneous action of the Fed unwinding its balance sheet, coupled with increased U.S. Treasury issuance, "may still tighten global liquidity conditions in the months ahead and weigh on several EM currencies." However, if U.S. inflation were to come in below expectations on Friday, this "could provide some more support to EM." Most EM currencies are up against the dollar on Wednesday. (olga.cotaga@wsj.com) 0804 GMT - Singapore manufacturing activity will likely slow further in 4Q with downside pressures coming from escalations in US-China trade tensions, Maybank says as it expects the trade-dependent economy to cool in coming quarters. Combined with impacts from July's residential-property cooling measures on the service sector and the bank predicts 2.6% GDP growth for this quarter, versus 2Q's 3.9%. As such, Maybank doesn't see Singapore's central bank tightening further next month. (saurabh.chaturvedi@wsj.com; @journosaurabh) 0750 GMT - Italy's budget for 2019, to be presented on Thursday, "remains a key point of uncertainty" amid varied news on the size of deficit but a below 2% gap could give further support to Italian government bonds, says Societe Generale. "A sub 2% deficit may provide BTPs with further support but we continue to see significant uncertainties around passing the budget and [credit] ratings," say Societe Generale's rates strategists. Italian government bond prices have firmed in recent days, driving yields lower, on hopes that the country's government will present a market-friendly budget plan for next year. The 10-year BTP yield is trading at 2.86%, down one basis point, according to Factset. Yields move inversely to prices. (emese.bartha@wsj.com; @EmeseBartha) 0727 GMT - The 10-year Italian BTP-German Bund yield spread should narrow toward 200-210 basis points if Italy's macro numbers for 2019 are as "constructive" as UniCredit expects, says rates strategist Chiara Cremonesi, referring to a budget deficit close to 2%. Italy's government is expected to present its budget draft for 2019 on Thursday. The 200-210 basis point spread is an initial target and the tightening could be even more pronounced "if some of the non-resident investors that sharply reduced their exposure to Italian government bonds in May and June returned, Ms. Cremonesi says. The spread is currently 235 basis points, according to FactSet. Investors with a more long-term strategy may wait rating reviews by Moody's Investors Service and S&P Global Ratings before extending their exposure to Italy, though, Ms. Cremonesi says. (emese.bartha@wsj.com; @EmeseBartha) 0721 GMT - Italy's funding outlook until year-end looks "smooth," says Chiara Cremonesi, rates strategist at UniCredit. She calculates that after Thursday's end-of-the-month government bond auction, Italy will have to issue around EUR35 billion in medium- and long-term debt until year's end. UniCredit expects Italy's average monthly issuance at EUR17 billion in October and November, down from a monthly average of EUR20 billion in the year to date, she says. UniCredit expects the Italian treasury to cancel the mid-December bond auction, in line with previous years. The analyst says net supply will be negative until the end of the year as issuance will be accompanied by EUR54 billion of redemptions in the October to December period. (emese.bartha@wsj.com; @EmeseBartha) (END) Dow Jones Newswires September 26, 2018 06:06 ET (10:06 GMT)

Title: Fed Rate Decision: What to Watch | Consumer Rate Rises Modest | Argentine Central Banker Resigns | Bankers vs. Activists | Derby's Take: Time to Put ‘Accommodative' Fed Language Out of Its Misery? The Wall Street Journal's central banking newsletter for Wednesday, September 26, 2018
Article: Derby's Take: Time to Put ‘Accommodative' Fed Language Out of Its Misery? Federal Reserve Readies Third Interest-Rate Increase of 2018 Modest Consumer Rate Rises Based on Variety of Factors Argentina's Central Bank President Resigns Bankers vs. Activists: Battle Lines Form Over Low-Income Lending Rules Time to Put ‘Accommodative' Fed Language Out of Its Misery? Federal Reserve watchers are split over whether the central bank will remove "accommodative" in describing its monetary policy when it releases its latest statement Wednesday. The term indicates Fed interest-rate policy remains supportive of the economy. And for some time now, it has been a signal more rate rises were coming. But now, the Fed's at a crossroads. Officials generally believe rate rises will no longer stop at neutral levels but go beyond that. With the unemployment rate well under what officials view as its sustainable level, and inflation hanging around the 2% target, monetary policy may have to lean against the economy's momentum to prevent overheating and keep the expansion going. Fed officials also are shifting their views about what constitutes a neutral level of interest rates. Fed Chairman Jerome Powell said in August he is less inclined to guide the economy by variables that rely on unmeasurable estimates, which means it may be harder to know when policy is no longer accommodative. At the same time, there are signs that the natural rate of interest, which still is looked to by many Fed officials, is shifting higher. All those moving pieces have left economists split as to whether "accommodative" lives or dies in the Federal Open Market Committee statement. "Fed officials have been increasingly uncomfortable describing policy in terms of estimates of R-star," economists at J.P. Morgan wrote in a note, referring to the so-called natural rate of interest. "It is against this backdrop that we anticipate the statement will remove previous references to policy being ‘accommodative.'" Wrightson ICAP's economists also see the word dropping out, as officials chop off a vestigial limb. "It is just the next step in the Fed's ongoing effort to disengage from the forward guidance framework that was part of its response to the Great Recession," the forecasting firm said. Jefferies economist Ward McCarthy expects "accommodative" to stay in the statement, but he expects officials to "modify the wording to convey the message that policy is becoming gradually less accommodative." Goldman Sachs economists say the word is "a touch more likely than not to remain," although they say that the rate forecasts shown in the central bank's "dot plot" are the far more important variable right now. NatWest Markets economists also see a case for the status quo. "Given that the funds rate will still be below participants' views of the long-run neutral rate after the September hike, we expect the FOMC to again indicate that ‘the stance of monetary policy remains accommodative,'" as officials did in their most recent FOMC statement. Key Developments Around the World Federal Reserve Readies Third Interest-Rate Increase of 2018 The Federal Reserve is prepared to raise short-term interest rates by a quarter percentage point after its two-day policy meeting concludes Wednesday, the eighth such move since late 2015. Officials will also present revised projections of future rate moves along with their outlook for inflation, employment and growth. The central bank releases its policy statement and the forecasts—the so-called dot plot—at 2 p.m. EDT. Fed Chairman Jerome Powell takes media questions at 2:30 p.m. Here is a look at what to watch. Modest Consumer Rate Rises Based on Variety of Factors U.S. consumer borrowing costs have drifted higher in recent months ahead of the Federal Reserve's likely decision Wednesday to raise short-term interest rates, though the increases have generally been modest. Average rates for credit cards, 30-year mortgages, auto loans and home-equity lines of credit have all risen since June 13, when the central bank announced a quarter-percentage-point increase in its benchmark rate and penciled in two more such moves this year. J.P. Morgan Goes Looking for Job-Market Bubbles, Sees a Few Candidates Most Federal Reserve officials reckon that, at a 3.9% jobless rate, the job market is running hotter than what they consider to be sustainable. The strength of the job sector raises the question: Have any parts of the labor landscape become overheated? According to a note from J.P. Morgan economist Jesse Edgerton, a jobless rate that has blown through the Fed's estimate of a 4.5% sustainable rate hasn't led to a lot of worrisome overheating, at least not yet. But he estimates that if things turned south for the economy, the tech and restaurant sectors look most inclined to take it on the chin. ECB Projects U.S. Could Be Biggest Casualty of a Global Trade Conflict The U.S. economy could shrink about 2% in the first year of a trade war with the rest of the world, while China and other economies could gain, according to new research published Wednesday by the European Central Bank. ECB officials have been fretting publicly for months about the impact of rising trade protectionism on the export-focused eurozone. The 19-nation economy has slowed this year, just as the ECB starts to tilt away from years of easy money. Argentina's Central Bank President Resigns Argentina central bank President Luis Caputo resigned less than four months into his post as the government struggles to contain economic turmoil and social unrest while it renegotiates a bailout with the International Monetary Fund. Mr. Caputo on Tuesday cited personal reasons for his departure amid reports of disputes with the IMF over Argentina's exchange-rate policy. He will be succeeded by Guido Sandleris, a top Finance Ministry official who has a Ph.D. from Columbia University, specializing in finance, macroeconomics and the international economy. Mr. Sandleris had previously taught at Torcuato di Tella University in Buenos Aires and was a visiting researcher at the Federal Reserve Bank of Minneapolis and the IMF. Brazil's Central Bank Hints at Rate Increases Brazil's central bank Tuesday said inflation risks have increased but it will keep monitoring indicators before deciding on raising interest rates. Still, the bank hinted at potential rate increases in the near future. The bank said rising borrowing costs in developed economies are worsening the global scenario for emerging markets, while failure to pass economic reform in Brazil is also tilting the balance of risks. Both factors could lead to more inflation, the bank said. The assessment came out in the minutes to last week's monetary policy meeting, when the Selic benchmark rate was held at 6.5% for the fourth consecutive meeting as inflation remains below target and the economy sputters. Philippine Central Bank Official Indicates Rate Increase The Philippine central bank will "show a strong hand" when it announces its next policy decision Thursday, its deputy governor said Tuesday as he indicated that its key interest rate is set to rise again. In an interview with The Wall Street Journal on the sidelines of a meeting with U.K.-based investors, Diwa Guinigundo also said he expects global economic growth to slow, partly in response to the U.S. Federal Reserve's interest-rate rises, which should in turn persuade the U.S. central bank to ease up on the pace of tightening. Mr. Guinigundo said an increase was likely on Thursday and the move may not mark the end of the recent series of rate increases. Indonesia's Central Bank May Raise Interest Rates Indonesia's central bank is expected to stay on track to raise interest rates further amid expectations that the U.S. Federal Reserve will most likely raise its interest rates Wednesday. 11 out of the 14 economists surveyed by The Wall Street Journal predicted the central bank to raise borrowing costs when it meets on Thursday, with many citing preventing further outflow as the main factor. FINANCIAL REGULATION ROUNDUP SEC Moves to Kill Metric That Signaled Price Mismatch in Pot Fund Wall Street's top regulator may soon get rid of a controversial metric for exchange-traded funds that just last week warned investors that a popular marijuana fund was trading at inflated prices. The measurement, known as intraday net asset value, gives investors a way to compare the price of a fund against the up-to-the-minute value of its underlying holdings. ETFs are required to report the information every 15 seconds during the trading day. The Securities and Exchange Commission, as part of an overhaul of the rules governing the $3.7 trillion U.S. ETF industry, has proposed eliminating that requirement. Instead, ETFs would have to report net asset value only once a day, at the closing bell. Comments on the proposed rule changes are due Oct. 1. Shoppers Love Rewards Credit Cards. Retailers Hate Them Consumers have become addicted to credit cards with generous rewards programs. Retailers are trying to cut them off. Large merchants including Amazon.com, Target and Home Depot are pushing for the right to reject some rewards credit cards, which typically carry higher fees for merchants. They are likely to opt out of a roughly $6.2 billion settlement Visa, Mastercard and several large banks recently reached with merchants and continue to make their case in court, according to people familiar with the matter. The retailers are trying to end the card networks' "honor all cards" rule, which requires merchants that accept Visa- or Mastercard-branded credit cards to take all of them. Bankers vs. Activists: Battle Lines Form Over Low-Income Lending Rules When Steven Mnuchin looked to sell his OneWest Bank for $3.4 billion in 2014, a community group with an $800,000 budget tried to block the deal. That led to a nine-hour public hearing where speakers compared the bank's executives to the ebola virus and called for their imprisonment. Others voiced support. Four years later, Mr. Mnuchin is the Treasury secretary and his fellow executive at the bank, Joseph Otting, is now comptroller of the currency. And one of their big agenda items is an overhaul of the Community Reinvestment Act, a law passed in 1977 to combat redlining, a practice where banks wouldn't lend in lower-income communities. WEDNESDAY 7 a.m. EDT Czech National Bank releases policy statement 10 a.m. EDT U.S. Commerce Department releases August new-home sales 2 p.m. EDT U.S. Federal Reserve releases policy statement, economic projections 2:30 p.m. EDT Fed's Powell holds press conference in Washington 5 p.m. EDT Reserve Bank of New Zealand releases policy statement THURSDAY Time N/A Bank Indonesia releases policy statement Time N/A Philippines' Bangko Sentral Ng Pilipinas releases policy statement Time N/A Central Bank of Egypt releases policy statement 2:35 a.m. EDT Bank of Japan's Kuroda speaks at Japan Securities Dealers Association event 8:30 a.m. EDT U.S. Commerce Department releases August durable-goods data 8:30 a.m. EDT U.S. Commerce Department releases third estimate of second-quarter GDP 9:30 a.m. EDT ECB's Draghi speaks at European Systemic Risk Board conference in Frankfurt 10 a.m. EDT Bank of England's Carney, ECB's Villeroy de Galhau and Riksbank's Ingves speak on panel at European Systemic Risk Board conference in Frankfurt 11:30 a.m. EDT ECB's Lane speaks at European Systemic Risk Board conference in Frankfurt 1 p.m. EDT ECB's Praet speaks in London 2 p.m. EDT Dallas Fed's Kaplan speaks at forum for minorities in banking in Charlotte, N.C. 4:30 p.m. EDT Fed's Powell speaks on U.S. economy in Washington 6 p.m. EDT Bank of Canada's Poloz speaks in Moncton, New Brunswick 7:50 p.m. EDT Bank of Japan releases summary of opinions for Sept. 18-19 meeting VoxEU Post Studies Central Bank Swap Lines Swap lines between central banks in advanced economies have become a "significant part of the global financial architecture," Saleem Bahaj and Ricardo Reis write in a VoxEU column. They describe how such swap lines helped avert liquidity crises after the Sept. 11, 2001, terrorist attacks and the financial crisis that started in 2007. Now, there are about 160 bilateral swap lines between central banks around the world, they write. The authors say the lines "perform a basic function of liquidity provision based around cooperation between central banks" and they "incentivize cross-border gross capital flows." The Inevitable Sacrifice of Argentina's Central Banker "Someone has to walk the plank when you want something big from the International Monetary Fund," Daniel Moss writes for Bloomberg Opinion. "That's been true of IMF loans, generally, to emerging markets. And Argentina is into something big with the Washington-based lender. The country is looking for a top-up of its $50 billion credit line, and if President Mauricio Macri can demonstrate the country can pay its debts, then the interest rates demanded by investors should come down from their crippling levels." Mr. Moss adds: "A leader that turns to the IMF has to have economic officials who can disavow the past practices and oversee the required reboot. And thus the exit of Argentine Central Bank President Luis Caputo, who resigned Tuesday after a mere three months in the role. He pulled rates as high as 60 percent to try to steady the peso. That's firefighting, not something sustainable…IMF or no, Macri had to change course. No economy can survive interest rates that stratospheric. Let's hope he hasn't forced the wrong person overboard." The Fault Lies in R-Star and in Ourselves Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell should question the whole notion that r-star--or the neutral real interest rate at which monetary policy is neither accommodative nor restrictive--has any significant practical use for the central bank, writes Kevin Warsh for The Wall Street Journal. "In my view, r-star is not a beacon in the sky but a chimera in the eye," he writes. "The idea of a "neutral" rate is a useful fiction. It makes for an interesting academic thought experiment. In practice, though, it's unobservable, unpredictable, imprecise and highly variable. That makes it a poor guide for policy makers." U.S. consumer confidence hit a new 18-year high in September, a positive indicator for spending going into the holiday shopping season, as robust job growth and a strong economic outlook bolstered Americans' expectations for the future. U.S. home-price gains slowed for the fourth straight month in July, as higher mortgage rates begin acting as a brake on rapid price growth, offering some welcome respite for buyers. An index measuring manufacturing activity across the central Atlantic region expanded in September. The Federal Reserve Bank of Richmond said in a report its composite manufacturing index rose to 29 in September from 24 in August. Economists polled by The Wall Street Journal expected a reading of 20 in September.--Dow Jones Newswires New Zealand business confidence jumped in September to its highest level since May, helping to ease what has become the biggest source of the worry for the economic outlook, and challenging the central bank's view that interest rates might soon need to be cut. Send us your tips, suggestions and feedback. Write to: Jon Hilsenrath; Michael Derby; Nell Henderson; Jason Douglas; Paul Hannon; Harriet Torry; Kate Davidson; David Harrison; Kim Mackrael; Tom Fairless; Michael Maloney. Follow us on Twitter: @WSJCentralBanks, @NHendersonWSJ, @PaulHannon29, @michaelsderby, @wsj_douglasj, @HarrietTorry, @KateDavidson, @d_harrison, @kimmackrael, @TomFairless, @mikemaloneyny

Title: Fed poised to raise rates for third time this year
Article: WASHINGTON (AP) — The Federal Reserve is set Wednesday to raise interest rates for a third time this year and possibly modify the likely direction of rates in the months ahead. The big question is whether the strong U.S. economy, which has been fueled this year by tax cuts and increased government spending, could weaken next year, especially if President Donald Trump's trade fights begin to inflict damage and the benefits of tax cuts start to fade. If the Fed finds that prospect likely, it might signal Wednesday that it expects to slow its rate increases next year. The Fed's key short-term rate now stands in a range of 1.75-2 percent after two quarter-point increases in March and June. A similar rate hike Wednesday would raise that range to a still-low 2-2.25 percent. ART FILE- In this July 17, 2018, file photo Federal Reserve Board Chair Jerome Powell testifies before the Senate Committee on Banking, Housing, and Urban Affairs on "The Semiannual Monetary Policy Report to the Congress," at Capitol Hill in Washington. On Wednesday, Sept. 26, the Federal Reserve issues its latest policy statement and updates its interest-rate and economic projections before Powell holds a news conference. (AP Photo/Jose Luis Magana, FIle)

Title: US Fed Policy Still Hurts Emerging Market Currencies -- Market Talk
Article: 0815 GMT - Emerging market currencies "are not out of the woods" even though a Federal Reserveinterest rate increase later on Wednesday is widely expected, says UniCredit. The simultaneous action of the Fed unwinding its balance sheet, coupled with increased U.S. Treasury issuance, "may still tighten global liquidity conditions in the months ahead and weigh on several EM currencies." However, if U.S. inflation were to come in below expectations on Friday, this "could provide some more support to EM." Most EM currencies are up against the dollar on Wednesday. (olga.cotaga@wsj.com) 0804 GMT - Singapore manufacturing activity will likely slow further in 4Q with downside pressures coming from escalations in US-China trade tensions, Maybank says as it expects the trade-dependent economy to cool in coming quarters. Combined with impacts from July's residential-property cooling measures on the service sector and the bank predicts 2.6% GDP growth for this quarter, versus 2Q's 3.9%. As such, Maybank doesn't see Singapore's central bank tightening further next month. (saurabh.chaturvedi@wsj.com; @journosaurabh) 0750 GMT - Italy's budget for 2019, to be presented on Thursday, "remains a key point of uncertainty" amid varied news on the size of deficit but a below 2% gap could give further support to Italian government bonds, says Societe Generale. "A sub 2% deficit may provide BTPs with further support but we continue to see significant uncertainties around passing the budget and [credit] ratings," say Societe Generale's rates strategists. Italian government bond prices have firmed in recent days, driving yields lower, on hopes that the country's government will present a market-friendly budget plan for next year. The 10-year BTP yield is trading at 2.86%, down one basis point, according to Factset. Yields move inversely to prices. (emese.bartha@wsj.com; @EmeseBartha) 0727 GMT - The 10-year Italian BTP-German Bund yield spread should narrow toward 200-210 basis points if Italy's macro numbers for 2019 are as "constructive" as UniCredit expects, says rates strategist Chiara Cremonesi, referring to a budget deficit close to 2%. Italy's government is expected to present its budget draft for 2019 on Thursday. The 200-210 basis point spread is an initial target and the tightening could be even more pronounced "if some of the non-resident investors that sharply reduced their exposure to Italian government bonds in May and June returned, Ms. Cremonesi says. The spread is currently 235 basis points, according to FactSet. Investors with a more long-term strategy may wait rating reviews by Moody's Investors Service and S&P Global Ratings before extending their exposure to Italy, though, Ms. Cremonesi says. (emese.bartha@wsj.com; @EmeseBartha) 0721 GMT - Italy's funding outlook until year-end looks "smooth," says Chiara Cremonesi, rates strategist at UniCredit. She calculates that after Thursday's end-of-the-month government bond auction, Italy will have to issue around EUR35 billion in medium- and long-term debt until year's end. UniCredit expects Italy's average monthly issuance at EUR17 billion in October and November, down from a monthly average of EUR20 billion in the year to date, she says. UniCredit expects the Italian treasury to cancel the mid-December bond auction, in line with previous years. The analyst says net supply will be negative until the end of the year as issuance will be accompanied by EUR54 billion of redemptions in the October to December period. (emese.bartha@wsj.com; @EmeseBartha) 0713 GMT - The U.S. Federal Reserve is largely expected to raise the interest rate by 25 basis points to a corridor of 2% to 2.25% on Wednesday, hence the flat EUR/USD at 1.1766 in London morning trading. The Fed's monetary policy tightening is likely to end next year, says UniCredit, which means "most of the dollar's strength is behind us." The Fed could remove the word "accommodative" from Wednesday's statement, but most analysts think this is unlikely. Even if it does, "we would not expect this change to trigger any strong dollar buying," UniCredit says. (olga.cotaga@wsj.com) 0658 GMT - Germany's 0% October 2023 Bobl offers value on the German yield curve, having underperformed on the October 2021-October 2023-August 2025 yield "fly" over the past month and also on the 2-5-10-year curve, say Citigroup's rates strategists. The German Finance Agency will tap the October 2023 Bobl on Wednesday with EUR3 billion on offer. The "fly" is at the cheapest level since the launch of the October 2023 Bobl in July, Citi's strategists say. They add that the five-year sector has also underperformed by some 11 basis points on the 2-5-10-year curve. Auction results are due at 0930 GMT. (emese.bartha@wsj.com; @EmeseBartha) 0650 GMT - The recent volatility may make some investors cautious ahead of Germany's EUR3 billion tap of the October 2023 Bobl Wednesday, say Mizuho's rates strategists. In fact, they reckon, the fear of hawkish comments should keep outright investors away from the five-year maturity segment on the German yield curve until yields reach 0%. Volatility in the five-year maturity segment of the curve has been "material" around central bankers' comments this week, Mizuho's strategist say, adding that the October 2023 Bobl is also expensive on the April 2023-October 2023 Bobl roll. The auction bond is trading at a yield of -0.03%, according to Factset. (emese.bartha@wsj.com; @EmeseBartha) 0649 GMT - There's more pain ahead for the Indian rupee as oil prices continue to rise. Fitch Solutions now expect it to hit INR74 against the dollar in 2019, up from its previous forecast of INR69. Despite recent government assurances, the local currency hasn't firmed much; it is at INR72.64. Oil accounts for almost a third of India's total import bill and Fitch expects India's plan to cut Iranian oil imports amid U.S. sanctions to make the bill bigger, and also weigh on its terms of trade. It also expects troubles in Turkey and Argentina to continue to fuel broader risk-off sentiment across emerging markets. Finally, a hawkish Fed will pressure the rupee further. (debiprasad.nayak@wsj.com ) 0635 GMT - Germany's EUR3 billion tap of the October 2023 Bobl, a five-year federal note, "should be absorbed smoothly," despite the recent repricing in five-year bonds, say Commerzbank rates strategists. The small offer volume at the upcoming auction is a factor that could support demand but so is the fact that the bond may avoid further underperformance following the recent selloff in German bonds. "At yield levels close to 0%, further underperformance looks limited with the pool of traditional Bobl investors increasingly noticeable at positive yields," say Commerzbank's rates strategists. The Bobl is trading at a yield of minus 0.03%. Bond yields move inversely to prices. (emese.bartha@wsj.com; @EmeseBartha) 0622 GMT - Steady gains today left the Nikkei above 24000 for the 1st time since in 8 months as the index was able to overcome the impact from a number of companies' stock prices being adjusted lower amid looming dividend payments. The index finished at session highs in rising 0.4% to 24033.79; the ex-dividend impact was estimated at about 160 points and banks were among the underperformers for that reason. Some electronics and consumer-goods makers rose about 3% today despite continuing caution about US trade policies. Helping was the dollar briefly hitting a 2-month high and breaching Y113; it's now around Y112.90. Meanwhile, 10-year JGB yields remain at 0.125%. (kosaku.narioka@wsj.com) 0618 GMT - The German 10-year Bund yield trades little changed early in the day as attention turns to the U.S. Federal Reserve's rate decision. As the Fed is almost universally expected to raise the funds target range by another 25 basis points, "attention will thus be focused on the forward guidance, including the new 'dot plot' diagram, to gain insight into the plans for 2019 and beyond," say ING rates strategists. Germany's EUR3 billion tap of the October 2023 Bobl will also draw attention as the recent selloff pushed five-year bond yields to multi-month highs. The 10-year Bund yield trades at 0.53%, according to FactSet. (emese.bartha@wsj.com; @EmeseBartha) (END) Dow Jones Newswires September 26, 2018 04:15 ET (08:15 GMT)

Title: Clouds on horizon as trade wars, debt weigh on Asia's growth
Article: BANGKOK (AP) — Trade conflicts, rising debt and the potential impact from rising interest rates in the U.S. will likely dampen growth in the coming year, the Asian Development Bank said Wednesday in an update of its regional economic outlook report. The Manila, Philippines-based regional lender said Wednesday that it expects economic growth in Asia to remain at a robust 6.0 percent in 2018 but to slip to 5.8 percent next year. China's economy is expected to expand at a 6.6 percent annual pace this year but slow to 6.3 percent in 2019. It cited looming financial and trade shocks as the biggest sources of potential trouble. If the U.S. economy shows signs of overheating, interest rate hikes by the Federal Reserve, including one expected Wednesday to take the benchmark rate to 2-2.25 percent, could disrupt currency markets and other capital flows, leading to problems with bad loans. Overly high housing prices also are risks for China, Hong Kong, Malaysia and South Korea, the report said. But it said the bigger threat comes from potential damage to supply chains caused by trade conflicts, especially between the U.S. and China. President Donald Trump pushed ahead Monday with higher tariffs on $200 billion of Chinese imports. Beijing retaliated by imposing penalties on $60 billion of U.S. goods. The conflict stemming from U.S. complaints Beijing steals or pressures foreign companies to hand over technology, has the potential to shave 0.5 percentage points off of China's growth and 0.1 percentage points off of growth in the U.S., the report said. China and the United States earlier imposed 25 percent tariffs on $50 billion of each other's goods. Combined, the tariffs now cover nearly half the goods and services China sells America and nearly 60 percent of what the United States sells China. The damage will be worse if Trump carries out threats to raise tariffs on virtually all products imported from China, said the ADB's chief economist, Yasuyuki Sawada. But fast-growing Asia is quickly becoming such a large market that expanding trade within the region can help offset lost exports to the U.S., he said. "Intraregional trade in Asia is as high as almost 50 percent of total t rade and this seems to be increasing over time," he told The Associated Press in a phone interview. "Asia used to be a global factory and everyone viewed Asian economies as suppliers, but if we look, more than half of the global middle class is living in Asia." Also, even if Trump's tariffs strategy succeeds in reducing the U.S. trade deficit with China, the ADB report said, the deficit with Asia overall is unlikely to decline so much because other countries would likely be exporting more to make up the difference.
